Egypt's military will get its usual $1.3 billion this year from the U.S.
government, that despite concerns about a recent crackdown on democracy and human rights groups.
Today, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton waived some restrictions on the aid, angering many in Washington.
Senator Patrick Leahy, a Democrat from Vermont, placed conditions on U.S.
And those conditions include staying on the path to democracy.
Leahy says Egypt's temporary military rulers have not kept their promises to the Egyptian people and have been whipping up anti-American sentiment.
And I don't want us to be in a position where we look like it's business as usual and we are rewarding them for that.
Speaking by cell phone from a country road in Vermont, Leahy says it was a mistake for Secretary Clinton to wave the conditions on U.S.

He had been hoping the Obama administration would fund Egypt differently, not just put $1.3 billion in an Egyptian bank account in New York but rather, dole out the money little by little to maintain some leverage.
